intro: Brassica oleracea var. macrogongyla, commonly known as the Chinese broccoli, is a cultivar of the cabbage family characterized by its thick, leafy stems and florets. It is native to East Asia and is cultivated for its edible leaves, stems, and flower buds. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and has a short growing season, making it suitable for spring and fall planting. Its botanical features include a robust root system and a compact growth habit, which contribute to its resilience in various climates. The leaves are usually dark green and slightly hairy, while the stems are thick and fibrous.
